conclusion: Analyze the v-t graph to determine if the displacement difference is continuously increasing.
The graph shows two curves, A and B, representing velocities over time; x-axis is time, y-axis is velocity.
Displacement is the area under the velocity-time graph.
Displacement for A is the area under curve A; for B, it's the area under curve B.
Difference in displacement is the difference in areas under curves A and B.
Initially, both objects start from rest; curve A reaches a higher peak velocity than B and returns to zero before B.
Initially, both objects have zero displacement; area under A increases faster than B initially.
Difference in displacement increases as long as area under A is greater than B.
After A returns to zero velocity, B continues to accumulate area, potentially reducing the displacement difference.
The difference in displacement is not necessarily continuously increasing.
Final answer: No, the difference in displacement is not necessarily continuously increasing.
